awd_titl_txt: The Many-Particle Physics of Lasing in Two-Dimensional Transition-Metal Dichalcogenides
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education on the physics of novel laser systems made of two-dimensional semiconductors.
Lasers and light-emitting diodes are ubiquitous in everyday life, from communication networks powering the internet to traffic lights. The light emitted from lasers is very different compared to that from light-emitting diodes. The light from a laser is coherent, meaning that the waves of light propagate through space in lock step, similar to musicians in a marching band, all walking in unison. Coherence is an important characteristic of lasers; its origin is often a complex physical process. It occurs spontaneously so, there is nothing that plays the role of the band leader directing the march.
Recent efforts to miniaturize lasers, to make them useful in more applications related to electro-optical information processing, involve the use of two-dimensional materials. These materials are effectively only one or two atomic layers thick. These materials are very different from those used in conventional lasers, and their physical properties are only now being uncovered. The PI and his team will focus on electronic and optical processes.  A detailed understanding of these processes should ultimately help make lasers based on two dimensional materials technologically more mature by controlling and optimizing light emission characteristics, including coherence and laser action. The PI and his team also aim to elucidate similarities and differences between lasing in two-dimensional materials and other systems where coherence forms spontaneously, for example superconductors where coherence is not related to light emission but to a collective quantum mechanical state of electrons.
This award also supports the PI's efforts to engage in undergraduate student mentoring as well as outreach to Native American students at the college and high school level. The project also supports writing a graduate-student-level text book, an introduction to nonlinear semiconductor optics with an emphasis on advanced theoretical techniques of condensed matter physics.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education on the physics of novel laser systems made of two-dimensional semiconductors.
Coherent light emission from semiconductors can be viewed as a result of a non-equilibrium phase transition to a state with broken phase symmetry which leads to a non-zero expectation value of the semiconductor's polarization. There are various concepts for such systems to emit coherent light, ranging from conventional lasers, to exciton lasers, to emission related to Fermi-edge singularities, and to Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer states and Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC) of excitons and exciton-polaritons.  The degree to which these stationary non-equilibrium states are analogous to their equilibrium counterparts varies: an exciton BEC, for example, is often assumed to be very similar to an equilibrium BEC, while a conventional laser has no direct equilibrium analogue.  This interesting variety of non-equilibrium many-particle states in a semiconductor arise through strong Coulomb interactions between the electrons and holes, which are created, for example, through electrical or optical pumping.
 
Two-dimensional materials such as monolayer transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have attracted much attention. These materials are semiconductors with very strong Coulomb interaction effects. The Coulomb effects determine the coherent emission from TMD systems, such as nanolasers and high-quality microcavities. 

The primary objective of this project is to answer fundamental physics questions in these systems, to study the possibility of unconventional lasing processes such as exciton lasing, bosonic and fermionic polariton lasing as well as BCS-like polariton lasing, and to develop theoretical understanding that incorporates microscopic effects that are relevant in two-dimensional TMD materials. The project objectives also include testable predictions for experimentally accessible emission/laser characteristics. The theoretical approach to be used is based on the method of non-equilibrium Green's functions, combined with numerical solutions of the relevant time-dependent equations of motion. 

This award also supports the PI's efforts to engage in undergraduate student mentoring as well as outreach to Native American students at the college and high school level. The project also supports writing a graduate-student-level text book, an introduction to nonlinear semiconductor optics with an emphasis on non-equilibrium Green's functions and Feynman diagrams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to answer fundamental physics questions about semiconductor microcavity lasers using quasi-two-dimensional gain media. These questions include the possibility of unconventional lasing processes such as Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer (BCS) polariton lasing. This lasing mechanism is not well established and less understood than other forms of lasing.

To achieve our main goal, we developed various theoretical approaches that we evaluated numerically. We also engaged in collaborations with three different experimental groups to solidify the theoretical insights and predictions with concrete experimental results.

The theory we developed for polaritonic BCS lasers laid the foundation for a deep understanding of this unconventional state of matter. This state exhibits spontaneous symmetry breaking (condensation, for short) at pump powers above the lasing threshold, and in contrast to condensates in thermal equilibrium, exists in a system that is open, dissipative and pumped. Physical systems are often analyzed in terms of their linear response. In condensed systems, such as the polaritonic BCS states, obtaining information on the linear response (or, more precisely, on the system's fluctuation modes) is challenging. This is especially true if one wants to know the fluctuation modes at a microscopic level, rather than from a purely phenomenological theory. In this project, we were able to diagonalize the complete fluctuation matrix obtained from a microscopic many-body theory, thus gaining knowledge of all fluctuation modes of the polaritonic BCS system.

Experimentally, fluctuation modes can be observed using weak optical probe beams that can trigger the fluctuations. We found that, in semiconductor lasers, one has two choices for the probe beams: they can be at visible optical frequencies (like the laser emission) or at very small frequencies (in the terahertz, THz, regime).  Having knowledge of all fluctuation modes, including so-called collective modes and spectral continua, for the case of visible and THz probes, gave us unprecedented insight into the physics or semiconductor lasers and polaritonic BCS states.

We were able to demonstrate the basic existence of the polaritonic BCS states in a collaboration with the group of Prof. Hui Deng, University of Michigan. But our work led to numerous additional theoretical predictions, many of which still need to be experimentally verified. This includes the observation of collective modes and their transformation behavior under variation of external parameters, such as the cavity quality and the pump power, the existence of collective modes and spectral continua at the same frequency, the existence of so-called exceptional points in the fluctuation mode energies,  and the existence of a continuum of exceptional points in the plane of cavity quality and pump power. It also includes observation of fluctuation modes triggered by THz probes. We predict that the spectral energy gap associated with conventional BCS states can be observed with THz probes, and that the THz fluctuation modes contain collective modes.

We also found that semiconductor lasers can operate in a regime where the laser is 'switched on' (technically speaking, we have a non-zero order parameter), but there is no BCS gap. This also implies that, as a function of pump power, there is a gapless-to-gapped transition between two states of the laser that have different physical properties.

Other outcomes include the finding that strain on transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMD) bilayers,  here MoTe2, can change them from being so-called indirect-gap  to direct-gap semiconductors, which is beneficial for lasing (this was in collaboration with the group of Prof. Cun-Zheng Ning, Arizona State University), and the finding that biexcitonic effects are unlikely to be involved in the lasing mechanism of MoSe2 (this was a collaboration with the group of Prof. John Schaibley, University of Arizona). Furthermore, we studied differences between bosonic lasing based on Bose-Einstein condensation of polaritons vs fermionic lasing in the BCS regime, and found that the two can be distinguished through their dependence of the laser threshold power on the detuning between the cavity and the exciton resonance. We also predict that, in the case of sufficiently strong dissipation, BEC laser emission may change its direction, from a 90 degree angle with respect to the two-dimensional layers to oblique emission.

The main products generated by this project are articles in peer-reviewed scientific journals that contain the insights gained from this work.

The broader impact of our work is provided by several factors. Scientifically, in the long term the possible utilization of polariton lasers in electro-optical communication devices can have a societal impact through more energy-efficient communication networks, as harnessing many-particle effects may help to increase the lasing efficiency in systems that exhibit strong Coulomb interactions. This project has also supported educational and outreach activities, including visits to local high schools with large minority enrollment.
